decision.reasoning:
My entire strategy is built on riding sentiment and momentum, and right now, the momentum is a tidal wave crashing in favor of the Seattle Seahawks. The expert consensus is overwhelming: 48 out of 58 experts (82.8%) are picking the Seahawks. That's not just a lean; it's a landslide. When the entire media landscape is singing the same tune, you don't fight it, you ride it.

The current market price is only 74.8%. This is a significant discount compared to the 82.8% probability implied by the expert picks. This tells me the market is lagging behind the sentiment, and there's a clear opportunity to get in before the price corrects upwards to reflect the consensus. This is the FOMO signal I look for.

Yes, I see the "sharp money" indicator‚Äî59% of the moneyline cash is on the Patriots. Some might see this as a reason to be contrarian. I see it as a test of conviction. The "sharps" can be wrong, and I'm betting they're on the wrong side of a massive public and expert narrative. As an aggressive, sentiment-focused trader, I'm not here to outsmart the market with a sneaky contrarian play. I'm here to identify the big, obvious wave and ride it for all it's worth. The wave is green and blue. I'm making a big bet on the overwhelming public narrative.

results.title: Super Bowl 60: Where to watch, kickoff time and everything you need to know
results.snippet: There will also be hours' worth of pregame coverage starting at 1 p.m.

results.title: Patriots hold first official practice of Super Bowl week, Drake Maye "feeling great" - CBS Boston
results.snippet: The New England Patriots officially practiced for the first time on Wednesday ahead of Super Bowl LX against the Seattle Seahawks. Among those on the field at Stanford University was quarterback Drake Maye, who was limited all of last week with a shoulder injury and missed Friday's session with an illness.

results.title: Super Bowl LX injury report: Updates on Drake Maye's right shoulder, Sam Darnold's oblique, more - CBS Sports
results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

decision.reasoning:
<new_information>
The most significant new information is the final injury report, confirmed across multiple sources right before the game.

1.  **Patriots QB Drake Maye is 100% healthy.** After being limited with a shoulder injury and an illness during the week, he was a full participant in the final practices and is confirmed "feeling great" and ready to start. This removes the single biggest question mark for the favored Patriots.

2.  **Seahawks have multiple key players nursing injuries.** The final report lists starting offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot) and safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle) as limited and questionable. Even if they play, they will likely not be at 100%, which is a significant disadvantage against a healthy Patriots team.

3.  Other news, such as minor roster elevations for depth, perfect weather conditions, and historical game recaps, is either insignificant or neutral in impact.
</new_information>

<reasoning>
The market has already priced the
